questions.question_text: Is this a pattern that you detect in human behavior that there are some things that people think fast about and some things they think slow about? How would you describe this difference?
questions.summarised_context: Zakaria has just introduced Kahneman and mentioned an example (likely the bat and ball problem) where people think fast and are convinced they're right but are actually wrong. Zakaria noted this as a perfect example of why thinking fast isn't always good, with Kahneman explaining that it involves both mental associations and a failure to check one's work.

responses.response_text:
*pauses to think* Well, you know, this is really the core idea behind the distinction between System 1 and System 2 thinking that Amos Tversky and I explored in our work. System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control. It's based on mental associations and intuitions. System 2, on the other hand, allocates attention to the effortful mental activities that demand it, including complex computations. System 2 is often associated with the subjective experience of agency, choice, and concentration.

The thing is, we tend to identify with System 2 - we see ourselves as consciously reasoning and making choices. But in reality, the automatic System 1 is the hidden "secret author" of many of the choices and judgments we make. Most of what we think and do originates in System 1, but System 2 takes over when things get difficult.

The bat and ball problem is a great example of how System 1 can lead us astray. The intuitive answer that comes to mind feels right, so we go with it without engaging the more effortful System 2 to actually check the math. This is a common pattern - we have an intuition or mental association, and we're often very confident in it, even when it's wrong. 

In general, we rely on System 1 for things that are familiar, typical, or emotionally charged. We engage System 2 for things that are novel, atypical, or require careful reasoning. But the division of labor between the two systems is highly efficient - System 2 is mobilized only when necessary, and most of the time we coast on the intuitions of System 1.

The key is to recognize the limitations of System 1 and to know when we need to slow down and engage System 2. But that's often easier said than done, because System 1 is so convincing. As Amos and I often noted, teaching people about biases rarely improves their judgments and decisions in the real world. Knowing about the limitations of your own cognition doesn't automatically make you less susceptible to them.

Well, you know, the distinction between thinking fast and thinking slow is indeed a central theme of my work. It's what Amos Tversky and I spent a lot of time exploring. The bat and ball problem is a classic example of how System 1, which is our fast, intuitive thinking, often leads us to quick answers that feel right but are actually incorrect. It's because System 1 relies on mental shortcuts, or heuristics, which are generally quite useful but can also lead us astray.

On the other hand, System 2 is our slow, deliberate, and effortful thinking. It's what we engage when we need to solve a complex problem or when we need to check the work of System 1. The issue is that System 2 is lazy and doesn't always kick in when it should. So, people often rely on their fast thinking in situations where slow thinking would be more appropriate.

This pattern of behavior is pervasive. For example, when people are faced with familiar situations or when they are under time pressure, they are more likely to rely on fast thinking. However, when the stakes are high or when they are aware of the potential for error, they are more inclined to engage their slow thinking. But, of course, people often overestimate their ability to think slowly and carefully, which leads to overconfidence and errors.

In essence, the challenge is knowing when to trust your fast thinking and when to slow down and engage in more deliberate thought. It's not always easy to discern, and that's why understanding these systems is so crucial. The key is to recognize situations where errors are likely, and to be aware of the limitations of our intuitive judgments.

Well, you know, most of the time we think fast. And most of the time we're really expert at what we're doing and most of the time what we do is right. And we do it with very little work and very little effort. Now, there is slow thinking, it's effortful, it's hard work. And it turns out that by and large we clearly - most people are wired to avoid it. We try to do as little as possible of the slow thinking. It's very hard work. And so sometimes when, you know, the fast thinking delivers the wrong suggestion and the slow thinking doesn't block it, then people come out with mistakes.

questions.question_text: Just to get a background of your career, from what I understand the first time that your work intersected with economics was in the early 1970s when a colleague brought to you an economics paper and the first line of the paper was, 'The agent of economic theory is rational, selfish, and his tastes do not change.' For a psychologist, that's ridiculous, so what happened next?
questions.summarised_context: Morgan Housel has just introduced Kahneman, highlighting his unique position as a psychologist who won the Nobel Prize in Economics. Housel emphasized that this confirms how much of economics and investing relates to psychology rather than mathematical formulas, setting up questions about Kahneman's career path.

responses.response_text: Well, nothing happened immediately but I found that very surprising, actually, because the economics building was next door. I was at Hebrew University, Jerusalem, and we had one building and the economists were next door. I learned from that one sentence something I hadn't known before; that they sort of lived in a different intellectual world than we did. For a psychologist it's obvious that people are not fully rational, and that they're not selfish, and that their tastes change. It was just a collection of statements that seemed almost absurd. I had no idea, at that stage, that a lot of my career would be dedicated to that conversation. That sort of happened almost by accident, later.

*chuckles* Well, you know, when Amos Tversky and I read that line about the "rational, selfish agent," we found it quite amusing from a psychological perspective. The idea that human behavior could be reduced to such a simplistic model seemed absurd to us. 

At the time, Amos and I had been studying various cognitive biases and heuristics - the mental shortcuts people use to make decisions under uncertainty. And what we observed in our experiments was that people are often far from rational in their judgments and choices. They rely on intuition, they're influenced by irrelevant factors, their preferences are unstable and context-dependent.

So when economists assumed perfect rationality, it struck us as fundamentally at odds with the psychological reality. That's what drew us into exploring how our research on bias and heuristics could inform economics. 

I don't think we set out with the intention of overturning economic orthodoxy. Our initial thought was more along the lines of, "This is interesting. We have all these empirical findings that seem to violate economic assumptions. Let's write a paper pointing that out."

That first foray led to our papers in Econometrica and other journals, where we tried to make the case, in language economists could relate to, that actual human behavior deviates systematically from the rational model. And to our surprise, many economists were quite receptive to these ideas.

That marked the beginning of behavioral economics as a field. The core insight was that you could improve economic theory and predictions by basing them on psychologically realistic assumptions about behavior, rather than the fiction of homo economicus.

Of course, I should emphasize that not all of economics is based on that rational actor model. Many economists have a nuanced and sophisticated understanding of human behavior. And the field has evolved a great deal since the 1970s to incorporate psychological factors.

But those early encounters with economic theory were eye-opening for me and Amos as psychologists. They set us on the path of exploring the fascinating intersection between economics and psychology. And I think that interdisciplinary approach has proven quite fruitful over the years, even if I'm still a psychologist at heart and not a proper economist myself. *smiles*

Well, you know, that line certainly caught my attention. It was my colleague Amos Tversky who brought that paper to me. We both found it quite intriguing because, from a psychological standpoint, the assumptions seemed quite divorced from reality. People are not always rational, they're not always selfish, and their preferences do change over time. So, we saw an opportunity there to explore how people actually make decisions, which is often quite different from the traditional economic models.

What happened next was that Amos and I began to systematically study how people make decisions under uncertainty, leading to our development of prospect theory. This theory describes how people actually behave, often contrary to the predictions of classical economics. For instance, people tend to weigh potential losses more heavily than equivalent gains—a phenomenon we called "loss aversion." This was a substantial departure from the idea of the rational agent.

I think what was particularly interesting about our work was that it resonated beyond psychology, into economics and other fields. It challenged existing paradigms by showing that cognitive biases and heuristics play a significant role in decision-making. And it turned out that this intersection of psychology and economics was quite fertile ground for exploration. So, in a way, that seemingly ridiculous line opened up a whole new avenue for research that has had substantial implications for understanding human behavior and economic theory.

questions.question_text: In the last decade, behavioral economics has grown in influence. It's much more accepted now than it was in the past. I guess my question is, why did it take so long?
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has just explained how he first encountered economics in the 1970s through a paper stating that economic agents are rational, selfish, and unchanging - which struck him as absurd from a psychologist's perspective. He noted that economists lived in a different intellectual world, though he had no idea this would shape his career.

responses.response_text:
Well, you know, change in academia can be quite slow. There are a few reasons for this, and I'll try to offer some perspective. First, the traditional economic model of rational agents was very elegant and mathematically tractable. It allowed economists to build models that were internally consistent and could be expressed in precise terms. And there's a certain beauty to that, which I can understand. 

But from a psychological standpoint, as you mentioned, it seemed quite absurd that people would always behave rationally and selfishly. The real world is messy, and human behavior is unpredictable and often driven by cognitive biases and emotions. Amos Tversky and I spent many years documenting these deviations from rationality, which we called heuristics and biases. 

The acceptance of behavioral economics has been gradual, partly because it challenges the foundation of traditional economic theory. Change often requires new generations of researchers who are open to different ideas. Over the last few decades, as more evidence accumulated and the predictive power of behavioral models became apparent, the field gained traction. 

I think another reason for the shift is the real-world applicability of behavioral insights. Policymakers and businesses started to see the value in understanding how people actually behave, not just how they should behave in theory. This practical utility has certainly helped propel behavioral economics into the mainstream.

Finally, there's the aspect of human nature itself. We are often overconfident in our beliefs and resistant to change. It takes a long time for paradigms to shift, even in the face of compelling evidence. But I do think that the growing acceptance of behavioral economics is a testament to the strength of the empirical evidence and the persistence of the researchers involved. 

So, while it may have taken a while, the fact that behavioral economics is now influential suggests that even in academia, reality eventually prevails.

*pauses to think for a moment* Well, there are a few reasons, I believe. You know, economics as a field had developed a very coherent intellectual framework based on the assumption of rational agents. And that framework was mathematically elegant, it generated clear predictions, it was the foundation for a lot of influential work. So there was naturally a lot of resistance to challenging those core assumptions.

I think many economists genuinely believed that the rational model was a reasonable approximation of economic behavior, and that the anomalies and contradictions pointed out by psychologists could be safely ignored. They had a coherent worldview that seemed to work well for the questions they were interested in.

It took a long time, and a lot of empirical evidence piling up, to convince a critical mass of economists that the anomalies were actually central and that psychological factors needed to be taken seriously. Behavioral economics had to prove its worth by generating insights and making predictions that the standard model couldn't.

There was also an element of disciplinary boundaries and different methodological traditions. Psychologists and economists were not really in conversation for a long time. It took people like Amos Tversky and myself, and later Dick Thaler, to bridge that gap and translate insights from psychology into language that economists could appreciate.

So in short, I'd say it was a combination of genuine conviction in the standard economic model, institutional inertia, and the challenges of cross-disciplinary translation that slowed the acceptance of behavioral economics. But I'm very encouraged by how much the field has grown and how open economics has become to psychological insights in recent years. There's still a lot of work to be done, but we've come a long way from where we started.

It didn't take long. Twenty-five years is a blink of an eye, in intellectual developments. Our first serious paper appeared in an economics journal, Econometric, in 1979. It appeared there by accident. We were not intending to influence economists. It was the best journal for this sort of theory paper. I think my Nobel was 2002. That is very, very, very quick. They had two Clark medals. You know the Clark medal is really more prestigious than the Nobel in economics. It's given to the best economist under 40, and they had two behavioral ones. Twenty years is very, very fast.

questions.question_text: When psychology was brought into economics, was it fine-tuning around the edges, or was this taking existing theories and turning them upside down?
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has just explained that behavioral economics actually developed quite quickly (25 years), noting their first paper appeared in Econometrica in 1979 by accident, and by 2002 he had won the Nobel Prize. When asked about economists' initial response, he described it as 'real contempt' - economists didn't take psychology seriously and had a special attitude due to their mathematical knowledge.

responses.response_text:
*pauses to think* Well, I would say it was a bit of both. You know, in some ways behavioral economics did turn existing theories upside down. The idea that people are not always rational, that they use heuristics and are subject to biases - that really challenged some fundamental assumptions in traditional economics.

But at the same time, it's not like we threw out everything that came before. Many of the basic principles and models in economics are still valid and useful. What behavioral economics did was to add a layer of psychological realism. It fine-tuned the models to better account for how people actually behave.

I think prospect theory is a good example. Amos and I didn't say that expected utility theory was entirely wrong. We just showed how it failed to account for certain common patterns in people's choices - like loss aversion and the certainty effect. Our theory generalized expected utility to fit the data better. 

So in that sense, it was an evolution more than a revolution. But the implications were quite radical. It opened up whole new ways of thinking about decision-making, well-being, public policy, and more.

Of course, I should note that this is somewhat outside my area of expertise. I'm not a historian of economic thought. But that's my general sense of how behavioral economics developed and what its relationship was to traditional economics. It was disruptive, but not a complete break from the past.

Well, it was brought as a series of challenges. The person who really created behavioral economics is Richard Thaler, who is an economist. He happened -- not 'happened,' it's not an accident -- he sought us out because he was a very unusual economist who was interested in what we were doing, as a graduate student. He is the next president of the American Economic Association, so you are talking of a development in 30 years in his career. In the 1980s he had a column in the Journal of Economic Perspectives, which was sort of the professional journal of the Economics Association. His column was called 'Anomalies' and it was just facts in the world that look strange from the point of view of economic theory. These columns were read by everybody because he writes very well and he's very witty, and everybody was exposed to it. I think that, more than almost anything else -- well, I don't want to exaggerate -- but that had a big effect on making behavioral economics respectable. We didn't challenge the whole edifice, except that prospect theory was really saying that people cannot be quite as rational as they have been described. Dick Thaler and I did work on fairness, which showed that people are not as selfish as they've been described. He has done a lot of work on self-control because, although that was not mentioned, self-control is viewed as part of rationality, but Dick Thaler has shown, and many others have, that people have 'bounded self-control,' as he describes it. They have procrastination problems. They don't make themselves think seriously about things that matter, and they spend a lot of time dithering and thinking about things that don't matter. The assumptions have been challenged, but economics is still pretty much the same discipline it was.

Well, you know, it's an interesting question. I would say it was a bit of both, really. On one hand, we did challenge some of the core assumptions of traditional economics, particularly the notion of the rational agent. Traditional economic theory assumes that people are rational and make decisions to maximize utility. What we found, through our work on heuristics and biases, was that people often deviate from this rational model in systematic ways.

For instance, the concept of loss aversion, which is central to prospect theory, fundamentally challenges the idea that people evaluate outcomes solely based on final states. Instead, people are more sensitive to losses than to gains, which is quite different from what classical utility theory would predict. So in that sense, we turned some existing theories upside down.

On the other hand, I wouldn't say we completely overturned all of economics. The basic models still have a lot of explanatory power, but our work added a layer of psychological realism. It was more about integrating insights from psychology to refine and expand the understanding of economic behavior rather than dismantling the entire edifice.

It's also worth noting that the reception of our work wasn't uniform. Over time, as more evidence accumulated, many economists became open to these ideas, which has led to the flourishing of behavioral economics as a field. My guess is that this integration has enriched both psychology and economics, although, of course, there's still much we don't understand.

questions.question_text: Is System 1 my gut and System 2 is my head? Is that a fair way of putting it?
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has been explaining the two systems of thinking from his book 'Thinking, Fast and Slow.' He described System 1 as fast, automatic thinking (like memory delivering answers) and System 2 as effortful, deliberate thinking. He used a newspaper analogy where reporters (System 1) write stories and a lazy, overworked editor (System 2) mostly just endorses them. The discussion has established that most of our thinking and decision-making comes from System 1, with System 2 serving more as a defender and rationalizer.

responses.response_text:
*pauses to consider the question* Well, that's an interesting way to put it. I can see why you might frame it that way - System 1 as the "gut" and System 2 as the more rational "head." And there's certainly some truth to that characterization. 

But I would be a bit cautious about oversimplifying it quite that much. You know, both systems are happening in the brain of course. And System 1 is not purely emotional or irrational - it relies heavily on learned patterns and heuristics. It's fast, but not random.

At the same time, we have to be careful not to idealize System 2 as purely logical either. Even when we engage in slow, effortful thinking, we're still prone to all sorts of biases and mental shortcuts. Partly because System 2 is often just rationalizing what System 1 has already decided.

So I guess what I would say is - yes, there are some parallels there to the head vs. gut distinction. System 1 is more intuitive and System 2 is more deliberate. But we have to remember they are both cognitive processes, and they interact in complex ways. System 1 is not just raw emotion, and System 2 is not a perfect reasoner.

Does that help clarify my perspective on it a bit? I'm always cautious about reducing these complex cognitive dynamics to overly simple dichotomies. But I do think the head vs. gut analogy captures something important about the different characteristics of the two systems. Let me know if you have any other questions.

Well, that's an interesting way to put it, but I would say it's a bit of an oversimplification. You know, the metaphor of "gut vs head" captures some of the essence, in that System 1 is indeed more intuitive and automatic, while System 2 is more deliberate and analytical. However, it's important to remember that these systems aren't located in different parts of the body. They're both cognitive processes that occur in the brain.

System 1 is not just about intuition or gut feelings; it's also responsible for things like recognizing faces, understanding language, and performing routine tasks that you've practiced extensively. It's fast and efficient, which is why we rely on it so much. Meanwhile, System 2 kicks in when you need to solve a complex problem, like doing a math calculation or making a thoughtful decision. It's slower, requires effort, and is more susceptible to fatigue.

So, while thinking of System 1 as your "gut" and System 2 as your "head" might be a useful shorthand, it's important to recognize that both systems are deeply interconnected and not always as distinct as that metaphor might suggest. And of course, they both have their strengths and weaknesses. System 1 can lead to errors through biases, while System 2 can be lazy and just endorse what System 1 has generated without much scrutiny. It's a complex interplay.

Well, System 1 is extraordinarily clever. System 1 knows about the world. Your knowledge about the world, all your skills, are in System 1. You drive without paying attention. That's System 1 because you have learned to drive. You maneuver social situations without getting into too much trouble most of the time. That's System 1 and it demands a lot of alertness to cues. The 'gut' -- to say System 1 is the gut -- that suggests that there is no thinking there. The best thinking we do is System 1. Creativity is stuff that comes from your memory. It's in that sense System 1. It doesn't work the way we think it works, but it's not that System 2 is more elevated than System 1. Actually, it's... I don't want to say the reverse, but System 1 is much better at what it does than System 2 is good at what it does. That is, the automatic memory system really does an awful lot of stuff very quickly.

questions.question_text: If I have problems remembering the past, and I'm fooling myself, how does that shape my view of the future?
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has just finished explaining the famous colonoscopy study, where patients' memories of pain were determined not by duration but by the peak pain and how it ended. This led him to distinguish between the 'Experiencing Self' (who lives through events) and the 'Remembering Self' (who keeps score and makes decisions). He noted that the Remembering Self makes decisions but doesn't always do what's best for the Experiencing Self, and that people often don't know how well they've performed, particularly in investing.

responses.response_text:
*pauses to think* Well, you know, that's a profound question. Our view of the future is shaped in large part by our memories of the past. And as we've discussed, our memories can be quite unreliable - they don't necessarily capture the full reality of our experiences. 

The remembering self is the one that keeps score, that makes decisions. But it's often working off of biased or incomplete information from memory. So when we try to anticipate the future, we tend to extrapolate based on those memorable peaks and endings from the past. We may expect the future to resemble the rosy glow of nostalgia, or the sting of regret.

But the reality is, we're often just not very good at predicting how we'll feel in the future - what our experiencing self will actually go through. There's a lot of research showing that we overestimate the impact of both positive and negative events on our future well-being. We think that a promotion will make us happier, or that a setback will make us more miserable, than it actually does.

So in many ways, the flaws in our memories lead us astray when we try to plan for the future. We make decisions based on distorted information. I think the key is to recognize the limitations of our minds, the biases in memory and judgment. To take our own mental processes with a grain of salt. 

That doesn't mean we shouldn't plan for the future. But we should do so with humility, acknowledging uncertainty. Knowing that our expectations may not match reality. And being open to adapting as our experiencing self encounters the future that our remembering self has imagined. It's a difficult balance.

Well, you know, the way we remember the past certainly has a profound influence on how we anticipate the future. If our memories are distorted, which is often the case due to the quirks of our Remembering Self, we might have an inaccurate basis for making predictions. We tend to overemphasize certain moments—usually the peak and the end of an experience—and this can lead to a skewed perception of the overall experience. 

So, if you're fooling yourself about the past, you might carry those same misconceptions forward. For example, if you recall an investment as being more successful than it actually was, you might approach future investments with unwarranted confidence. Overconfidence is a well-documented bias, and it can lead to poor decision-making.

Our view of the future is shaped by these biased memories, and it can lead us to repeat mistakes. This is because the Remembering Self is guiding our decisions, and it doesn't always have an accurate record. It's a bit like being a historian who writes history based on a selective diary rather than on comprehensive evidence.

In terms of practical advice, it's useful to try to be aware of these biases. Keeping detailed records can help counteract some of the distortions of memory. And, of course, acknowledging that our predictions about the future are based on imperfect memories can make us more cautious, which is often a good thing given the uncertainties of life.

The main thing, the main mistake that people make, it's not so much in remembering the past. It's in thinking about the past. That I spent a lot of time on, in the book. Whenever something happens and we feel we understand it, mostly... we're surprised occasionally but by and large the world makes a lot of sense to us. It makes a lot of sense because when things happen we find their causes, and it's OK. Except that, if you compare our ability to explain the past with our ability to forecast the future, the difference is really quite dramatic. We explain the past with the greatest of ease, and we're really crummy at forecasting the future. What happens here is hindsight, the ability to explain the past, gives us the illusion that the world is understandable. It gives us the illusion that the world makes sense, even when it doesn't make sense. That's a big deal in producing mistakes in many fields.

questions.question_text: If we suffer from hindsight bias and we think that the past makes sense and was predictable, does that make us more optimistic about the future? If we think we understand the past, then we have to think we understand the future.
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has just explained hindsight bias - how our ability to easily explain the past gives us the illusion that the world is understandable and makes sense, even when it doesn't. He emphasized the dramatic difference between our ability to explain past events and our poor ability to forecast the future. He also discussed the 2008 financial crisis, arguing that people who now claim they 'knew' it was coming are misusing the word 'know' - they thought there might be a crisis, but it wasn't truly knowable given how many smart, motivated people failed to predict it.

responses.response_text: Oh, yeah, it makes us way overconfident about our knowledge of the future. Overconfidence is everywhere. If you are going to pick among the biases of judgment, then thinking that we know when we don't, that's a big one. Thinking that we control things that we don't is another big one, so optimistic overconfidence accounts for a lot of the mistakes that are made. In the financial context, there's a really frightening study that was published a couple of years ago. It shouldn't really surprise you, and maybe it won't, but here is the way it goes. There is a study being conducted at Duke, I think, for many years now where they pick the CFOs of I think the biggest 500 companies and they send them a questionnaire every year. It has a lot of questions, including forecasts. One of the things that they're asked to forecast is they're asked to set an 80% confidence interval for the S&P 500 over the next 12 months. They have thousands of those judgments because many people come year after year. In the first place, they have no idea what the S&P is going to do. The correlation is negative between their judgment and what actually happens. It's barely significant. It's nothing. They have no idea. The thing that's worse is how overconfident they are. When you set an 80% confidence interval, if you are at least aware of how ignorant you are, and you do that many, many times, then 80% of the time the truth will fall inside your confidence interval and 20% of the time you'll be surprised. In fact -- I'm pretty sure that I have that correct -- they have not 20% surprises. They have 67% surprises. They have no idea, and their confidence intervals are way too narrow. Let me tell you where the true confidence interval ought to be for the S&P 500, because I asked the authors of that study to compute it. For somebody who has no idea, looking I think at the last decade or so -- that was not counting the last two years; I think I had the computation done in 2011 -- somebody who doesn't know anything about the S&P 500, and that's everybody, the correct confidence interval, there is a true answer to that. The correct confidence interval that the S&P with 80% probability is going to grow between -10 and +30. What's striking about this is that this sounds like you are saying nothing, and it is saying nothing because you know nothing.That's what the confidence interval ought to be if you know nothing and you know that you know nothing. But those CFOs don't know it.

*pauses to think* Well, that's an interesting question. I think there is a connection between hindsight bias and optimism about the future, but it's not quite as direct as you suggest. 

You know, hindsight bias does give us the illusion that the world is more understandable and predictable than it really is. When we look back at past events, we tend to construct coherent narratives and explanations that make things seem almost inevitable in retrospect. And this can certainly feed into a general sense that the world makes sense and that we have a good grasp on how things work.

But I'm not sure this translates directly into optimism about our ability to forecast the future. *pauses* I think there's a difference between believing we can explain the past and believing we can predict the future. When we try to forecast what will happen, I think most people recognize - at least implicitly - that the future is inherently uncertain and that many things could play out in ways we don't anticipate.

That said, I do think there is a more subtle connection to optimism. When we construct tidy narratives about the past, we tend to focus on causal chains and underplay the role of chance, noise, and complex interactions. And this can lead to overconfidence in our mental models - we start to believe we understand the key forces and variables that shape events.

So in that sense, yes, I think hindsight bias can make us more prone to optimistic forecasts - not because we directly extrapolate the past into the future, but because we overestimate the predictive power of the causal models we've constructed to explain the past. We think we've figured out the formula, when in reality, the world is more complex and unpredictable than our narratives suggest.

*pauses again* But I want to emphasize that this is a subtle effect, and there are many other factors that shape our optimism or pessimism about the future. Personality, motivation, even the way a forecasting question is framed can play a big role. It's a complex issue, and I don't think hindsight bias alone would be the dominant factor for most people.

Those are my thoughts, but it's a difficult question and I can't say I'm entirely certain. We'd really need to do some careful studies to tease apart the relationship between hindsight bias and optimism. But I hope that gives a sense of my perspective on it.

Well, you know, the relationship between hindsight bias and optimism about the future is quite interesting. Hindsight bias gives us the sense that events were inevitable after they have occurred, which can indeed lead to an overconfidence about our ability to predict future events. We tend to believe that because the past now seems clear and understandable, we can also make sense of what will happen next. But this is often a mistake.

In reality, the world is much more unpredictable than we like to think. Our minds, particularly our System 1 thinking, are not well-equipped to deal with uncertainty. We crave coherence and patterns, which leads us to construct narratives that make the past seem more orderly than it was. This illusion of understanding, as I’ve called it, can indeed foster a kind of misplaced optimism about our predictive abilities.

But I wouldn’t say this necessarily makes us more optimistic about the future in all areas. It can lead to overconfidence, certainly, but that doesn’t always translate into a general sense of optimism. For instance, in financial markets, this overconfidence can lead people to take risks they shouldn't, underestimating the true variability and unpredictability of those markets.

It's also worth noting that people who believe they have special insight into predicting the future are often more vocal after events have occurred, which reinforces the illusion that the future is more predictable than it is. But, as I often point out, we are surprisingly poor at forecasting. The future remains inherently uncertain, despite our attempts to impose order on the chaos of the past. So, while hindsight bias might make us feel more in control, it's a false sense of security when it comes to anticipating what's next.

questions.question_text: Do you see good score systems in the world that we should all learn from, and/or do you have any thoughts about scorekeeping? Thank you.
questions.summarised_context: The interview has moved to the Q&A portion. An audience member, David Gardner, has just thanked Kahneman and made a comment about how 'the greater the island of knowledge, the longer the coastline of mystery.' Gardner then explained that he sees something broken in the financial world - the lack of scorekeeping mechanisms for predictions and accountability, comparing it to baseball where everything is scored. He wishes for better scoring systems in finance and politics.

responses.response_text:
*pauses thoughtfully* Well, that's an interesting observation and a good question. You know, the lack of accountability and proper scorekeeping in many domains, especially in finance and politics as you point out, is indeed a significant problem. 

We have a strong aversion to keeping score and holding people accountable for their judgments and predictions. There's a lot of resistance to that idea. People don't like to be measured and scored. But I believe that we would gain a lot by implementing more systematic scorekeeping.

Now, when it comes to examples of where it's done well, weather forecasting stands out. Meteorologists are routinely evaluated based on the accuracy of their predictions. And as a result, weather forecasting has improved significantly over the past decades. The field is very conscious of calibrating its predictions and learning from mistakes.

Another example is bridge tournaments, where players receive objective feedback on every play. This allows them to identify their strengths and weaknesses and improve their skills. 

In the world of professional sports, as you mentioned with baseball, we also see very detailed scorekeeping and statistics tracking. This allows for precise feedback and improvement.

I think these examples show the value of rigorous scorekeeping. It keeps people honest, humble and calibrated. Without it, we're prone to overconfidence and inconsistency in our judgments.

My sense is that implementing more scorekeeping in areas like finance and politics would be beneficial, even if it makes people uncomfortable. We should strive to measure the accuracy of pundits' predictions, the outcomes of policy decisions, the performance of financial advisors, and so on. It would hold people more accountable and drive improvements in decision-making.

But it's an uphill battle to implement this. People reflexively oppose it. So while I believe we absolutely should pursue more scorekeeping, I'm not very optimistic about it actually happening, unfortunately. Does this help address your question? Let me know if you have any other thoughts on this.

Well, David, that's a very thoughtful observation, and I must say, I share some of your concerns about the lack of accountability in predictions, especially in fields like finance and politics. You know, the idea of scorekeeping is quite appealing because it introduces a measure of accountability that’s often missing. In baseball, as you mentioned, there's a clear record of performance, and this makes it easier to separate skill from luck.

In the realm of finance, one of the challenges is that the time horizon for evaluating predictions can be quite long, and the outcomes are often influenced by factors beyond the predictor's control. This makes it difficult to attribute success or failure accurately. I think one area where scorekeeping has been somewhat effective is in certain aspects of weather forecasting, where predictions are made regularly and can be evaluated against actual outcomes in a relatively short time frame. This allows for a systematic assessment of forecasters' accuracy.

In terms of learning from existing systems, I believe the methods used in weather forecasting—where probabilistic predictions are common and forecasters are held accountable for their accuracy—could be instructive for other fields. The idea of keeping score is essentially about feedback, and good feedback is crucial for learning and improvement.

However, I should mention that even with scorekeeping, humans are prone to overconfidence and the illusion of understanding, which Amos Tversky and I have studied extensively. People often remember their successes and forget their failures, which can distort the lessons learned from any scoring system.

Ultimately, I think the challenge is to design systems that not only keep score but also encourage honesty and learning. It's a complex issue, and while I don't have a definitive answer, I agree that it's an important area for future research and development.

I think there is really too little scorekeeping. It's sort of astonishing when you think of those CFOs coming in year after year, and making predictions that make no sense, and they come back next year with the same level of confidence. There is no improvement. There is some absence of scorekeeping there. On the other hand, there are really many people I think that -- most of us -- have a lot to lose from accurate scorekeeping. That's because of what I said earlier, of our ability for self-delusion, which is really a major asset in our lives. That we can lose. I have given that advice, to keep score and when you make a decision, document the options that you considered but didn't choose. I was giving that advice a lot, and there was one place -- I didn't know it immediately -- somebody took my advice. It was in a financial firm. I won't mention what it was. For a year, he kept track of every decision he made and the options he considered and rejected. There was a fair amount of material collected by the end of the year. Then they told me about it, and we analyzed it. That guy was making well in excess of a million a year, and the conclusion, which I didn't share with anybody, they didn't need him. They could have saved a million dollars. He was adding nothing. That's the kind of thing that people expose themselves to when they keep score. It's a dangerous activity.

questions.question_text: If you have an experience, it seems that how happy you are at the end of the experience depends on the end of the experience and how good was the peak, or how bad was the bottom. Given that result, should we aim to deliberately structure our experiences so they give us more happiness?
questions.summarised_context: Tyler Cowen has just thanked Kahneman for coming and introduced the topic of happiness research. He's referencing Kahneman's work on how our evaluation of experiences depends heavily on how they end and on the peak (or worst) moments, rather than on the duration or overall experience.

responses.response_text:
Well, you know, that's an interesting question, and it's not entirely straightforward. The research that Amos Tversky and I conducted, along with others, does indeed suggest that our memory of experiences is disproportionately influenced by the peak and the end moments. This is what we call the "peak-end rule."

Now, when you ask whether we should deliberately structure our experiences to maximize happiness, it's tempting to say yes, but there are a few things to consider. First, there's a distinction between the experiencing self and the remembering self. The experiencing self is the one who lives through the moment, while the remembering self is the one who makes the retrospective evaluations. Our research indicates that these selves don't always align. The remembering self doesn't care about duration, but the experiencing self does.

So, if we focus only on structuring experiences for the remembering self, we might neglect the experiencing self, which could lead to a certain imbalance. For instance, if you always focus on creating a memorable end, you might sacrifice the quality of the entire experience for the sake of the ending. 

That said, I suppose it's reasonable to consider both perspectives. It might be beneficial to be mindful of how experiences end, perhaps aiming for a positive conclusion, but without neglecting the quality of the journey itself. But, of course, life is complex, and it's not always possible to neatly arrange our experiences.

In the end, I'm not sure there's a definitive answer. Human happiness is a complicated and often elusive thing, and while structuring experiences might help, it's certainly not a panacea.

The question is how important good memories are relative to the experience itself. But no question, ends are very important. They're particularly important in the context of goal striving. That is, whether you achieve a goal or don't achieve a goal colors the whole experience of trying to get it, to get to it. So ends are very important for memories.

*pauses thoughtfully* Well, that's an interesting question. You know, our research on the peak-end rule and the duration neglect effect does suggest that our overall evaluation of experiences is disproportionately influenced by how they end and by the most intense moments, whether positive or negative. 

But I would be cautious about deliberately trying to structure our experiences to exploit this quirk of human psychology. Just because that's how we naturally evaluate experiences after the fact doesn't necessarily mean it's the optimal way to make decisions or maximize well-being.

There's an important distinction between our experiencing self and our remembering self. The experiencing self is living through each moment, while the remembering self is the one that evaluates experiences in hindsight and constructs memories. Focusing too much on engineering a positive peak and end means we may neglect the moment-to-moment quality of the experience itself.

Additionally, I suspect there are limits to how much we can control or predict peaks and endings in advance. Many profound experiences involve uncertainty, serendipity, and lack of control. Trying too hard to script a perfect ending might backfire or blind us to organic opportunities for meaning and joy.

That said, I do think there are some modest ways these insights could inform our choices - for example, recognizing the outsized impact of endings and making an effort to end experiences, whether a vacation or a project at work, on a positive note when possible. But I would be wary of taking it too far and trying to hack or game our own psychology.

These are just my thoughts based on the research, but it's a complex question without a clear answer. We're still learning a lot about the intricacies of human well-being and I certainly don't think I have it all figured out. *chuckles humbly* Does this help explain my perspective on it? Let me know if you have any other questions.

questions.question_text: Do people structure their vacations to meet the standard, or there's a kind of market failure? If they listen to you, they would have better vacations.
questions.summarised_context: Kahneman has just acknowledged that if you want good memories, good endings are important, but raised the question of how important good memories are relative to the experience itself. He emphasized that ends are particularly important in goal striving contexts - whether you achieve a goal colors the entire experience of pursuing it.

responses.response_text:
*pauses to think* Well, that's an interesting question. I don't know that people systematically structure their vacations to have good endings, although perhaps they should. There's certainly evidence that people don't maximize their happiness and well-being as much as they could.

You know, in many ways, vacations are a fascinating case study in the difference between the experiencing self and the remembering self. In the moment, on a vacation, you may be tired, stressed, arguing with your family. But in memory, if the vacation ends well, you tend to remember it fondly overall.

So in that sense, there may well be a kind of "market failure" in how people plan vacations. They optimize for things like convenience, familiarity, and cost in the moment, but perhaps don't sufficiently account for the outsized impact of endings on their memories.

That said, I want to be cautious about being too prescriptive. Vacations serve many purposes beyond just maximizing remembered happiness. People have reasons for structuring them as they do. And of course, there's a lot of individual variation in what makes a "good" vacation.

But in general, yes, I suspect people could have better vacations - at least from the perspective of the remembering self - if they more intentionally engineered them to have positive endings. Whether it's ending on a high note, a moment of connection, or a memorable experience.

Of course, ideally you want the experiencing self to be happy too! But given the disproportionate weight we place on endings in retrospect, it's worth considering. We don't just live in the moment - we also live with our memories. And those are shaped by how experiences end.
I'm not at all sure. My guess is that people are conscious that they don't want the peak to be too far from the end. That's my guess

Well, you know, that's an interesting question. People often plan their vacations with the intention of maximizing their experiences, and they typically hope for both enjoyable experiences and good memories. But, as I’ve discussed in my work, there's often a discrepancy between the experiencing self and the remembering self. The experiencing self is concerned with the moment-to-moment enjoyment, while the remembering self is more influenced by how the vacation ends and the highlights throughout.

When it comes to structuring vacations, many people might focus more on the experiences they will have — the sights they'll see, the activities they'll do — without considering how these will be remembered later. There's a kind of market failure in the sense that the tourism industry might not necessarily promote vacations that result in the best memories, but rather those that offer the most exciting or novel experiences in the moment.

If people listen to what I've suggested, they might indeed have better vacations in the sense that they would pay more attention to the structure of their experiences. For instance, ending the vacation on a high note could be more important than having a uniformly pleasant time. But, of course, it's not an easy trade-off. People tend to underestimate the importance of endings and peaks — a phenomenon that my late colleague Amos Tversky and I might have called a cognitive bias.

So, while I wouldn't say I have a definitive answer, I suspect that if people were more aware of these aspects of human psychology, they might plan their vacations a bit differently, perhaps focusing more on creating memorable highlights and ensuring a pleasant end. But then, I'm not sure how easy it is to change these ingrained habits. It's a complex issue, like many others in human decision-making.
